channel.title: C++ reading from a file
channel.description:
I tried using fstream and getline to read text from a file, however I don't think I fully understand how I would apply it to this approach. My goal is to store this data into a 100 int array memory[].
In my text file, I have comments start with **, and that should make the program ignore that line.
An example of a normal line is: 00 +1099
The 00 is the array location where this data should be stored. The plus can be ignored I think, and the 1099 is to be stored in the array.
Later on in the program I would read the first two digits (10) and execute something off of them, while the last two (99) would be the array location modified.
I would really appreciate some help in this matter, as I'm a bit lost. This is for an enhanced version of the simpletron program from deitel's books.

item.title: C++ reading from a file
item.dc:creator: @z z
item.description:
@z wrote:

[quote=“Mopman, post:16, topic:395995”]I don’t think the pointer confusion is a matter of syntax.[/quote]Some people struggle with syntax too.

[quote=“abraham2119, post:17, topic:395995”][quote author=mutex_ link=topic=493174.msg3654264#msg3654264 date=1309912325]

[quote author=super_ link=topic=493174.msg3654200#msg3654200 date=1309909566]
lol it’s weird i never understood why people found pointers difficult
[/quote]Associating special characters with specific meanings can get tremendously difficult especially when you’ve picked up multiple programming languages, and (generally) any other related computing subjects.

For example, the “?” symbol:
PHP - <?php
Regex - optional metacharacter
Multiple languages - Ternary operator
etc.
[/quote][quote author=Mopman link=topic=493174.msg3654414#msg3654414 date=1309919554]
I don’t think the pointer confusion is a matter of syntax.
[/quote]I have met people who have had issues with syntax…

you are so fucking stupid…it’s not a matter of syntax but more a matter of not being able to understand the concept of manual memory allocation on the heap nor its necessity and further down the line comes the assumed complexity of pointer arithmetic and explicit casting to other primitive types[/quote]You call me ‘so fucking stupid’ for what reason? Because I outlined an issue that people have, with examples to convey? Did you not just do that too but without examples?

Read full topic

item.title: C++ reading from a file
item.dc:creator: @sanga282 sanga282
item.description:
@sanga282 wrote:

i would say read each line using getline and dump it into a string, then use an if statement to see if it starts with ‘##’ using find, if it doesnt then i’d use find to get the number you want to store in the array, convert to an int then stick into the array position (you shouldnt need to locate the array position at the start of the line because you an increment it all within a while loop from 0-99 unless you for some reason have your lines in a non sequential order)
EDIT:
forgot to say that you’ll wanna truncate the string as well to just isolate the number if they are preceded by plus signs use find to get the location and then remove the stuff before it and keeping whats in front of the plus sign up to length -1

Read full topic

item.title: C++ reading from a file
item.dc:creator: @synchronized2 synchronized_
item.description:
@synchronized2 wrote:

What about;

#include <iostream>
#include <fstream>

using namespace std;

int main() {
    ofstream WriteFile;
    WriteFile.open("MyFile.txt");
    if(WriteFile.is_open()) {
        WriteFile << "Hello World!\n";
        WriteFile << "Line 2";
        WriteFile.close();
    } else {
        cout << "Unable to open file.";
    }

    ifstream ReadFile;
    string line;
    ReadFile.open("MyFile.txt");
    if(ReadFile.is_open()) {
        while(ReadFile.good()) {
            getline(ReadFile, line);
            cout << line << endl;
        }
    } else {
        cout << "Unable to open file.";
    }

    return 0;
}

Read full topic

item.title: C++ reading from a file
item.dc:creator: @z z
item.description:
@z wrote:

[code=c]#include <stdio.h>

#define MAXSIZE 200
#define ARRSIZE 100

int main()
{
FILE *pointer;
char fn[MAXSIZE];
char line[MAXSIZE];
int line_c = 0,idx,data;
int arr[ARRSIZE];

for(idx = 0; idx < ARRSIZE; ++idx)
	arr[idx] = '\0';

printf("Enter filename: ");
scanf("%s",&fn);

if((pointer = fopen(fn,"r")) == NULL)
{
	printf("File cannot be read.\n");
	return 1;
}

while(fgets(line,sizeof(line),pointer) != NULL)
{
	sscanf(line,"%d +%d",&idx,&data);
	printf("[%d]: %d %d\n",line_c,idx,data);
	++line_c;
	arr[idx] = data;
}

fclose(pointer);

for(idx = 0; idx < ARRSIZE; ++idx)
{
	if(arr[idx] == '\0')
		break;
	printf("[%d]: %d\n",idx,arr[idx]);
}

}[/code]

Use fopen, fgets, and sscanf.

If you then wanted to split the 1099, you would use sscanf again:

... int exec, location; sscanf(arr[idx],"%2d%2d",&exec,&location); ...
%2d means to read only the first two integers from the given arr[idx].

Read full topic
